title: Evidence that the shingles vaccine prevents a good chunk of dementia cases
content: Thread ReaderPascal GeldsetzerSubscribe@PGeldsetzer1May 25 • 18 tweets • 24 min read Read on TwitterBookmarkSave as PDFBiggest thing to ever come out of my little group. Pls help spread this finding!We found clean, CAUSAL evidence that the shingles vaccine prevents a good chunk of dementia cases. So, could a virus cause Alzheimer’s->YES!Hear me out & see preprint: bit.ly/3MVqXU9🧵1/There’s recently been ⬆️ interest in the possibility that a virus may be involved in the causal pathways of dementia. Most attention has been on herpesviruses, incl the VZV that causes chickenpox and shingles, partly because of their lifelong latency (bit.ly/3nibvYk).2/In Wales starting in Sept 2013, the shingles vaccine was rolled out using an exact DOB cutoff. Those born on or after Sept 2 1933 were eligible, while those born earlier weren’t and remained ineligible for life. We analyzed EHR data for all of Wales with DOB exact to the week.3/We first show that just a one-week difference in age causes a massive (47 %-point) difference in the probability of ever getting the vaccine.This is paradise for getting at CAUSATION rather than correlation!4/After all, there’s no reason why those born one week before Sept 2 1933 should differ in anything from those born just one week later, EXCEPT for this diff in vacc receipt. This is just like a clinical trial: two exchangeable groups with only one getting the intervention.5/So, no need for the usual heroic assumption of perfect info on all confounders that make those who get the vacc different from those who don’t. This is crucial, and why our study is fundamentally different to other (all correlational) analyses in this area.What did we find?6/We first tried to replicate the vaccine’s known effect from clinical trials that it prevents shingles and PHN. It does – no surprise here but nice proof of concept.Now we test our real hypothesis: does getting vaccinated ⬇️ your chance of a dementia diagnosis years later?7/It does! We estimate that over a 7-year follow-up period, getting vaccinated averts one in five new dementia diagnoses. In the paper, we demonstrate through extensive robustness checks that it is essentially impossible that this finding is due to confounding.8/Given how robust this finding is across a large variety of specifications and series of robustness checks, it’s also extremely unlikely to be due to pure chance.9/We then show that the vaccine has no effect on any other common causes of morbidity or mortality. This is unlike correlational analyses that usually suffer from bias because healthier/more health motivated folk with better healthcare access are more likely to get vaccinated.10/Shingles is more common in women + ⬆️ recognition that the causes of Alzheimer’s may differ by sex (bit.ly/3HqGh8k). We find strong protective effects of the vaccine for women but none for men, and that this diff is driven by Alzheimer’s (not vascular) dementia.11/What’s needed next? 1) Randomized trials w/ precise cognition measures to determine exact effect size + optimal pop groups & time interval for vacc. Any interest @Merck @merckgroup @MerckFoundation @Merck_lifesci @GSK @GSKUS @GSK_bio? I have ideas for doing this ethically.12/2) Research to understand how the shingles vaccine prevents or delays dementia; and 3) trials to determine if the vaccine reduces (or maybe even reverses) cognitive decline among those with MCI or mild dementia.#neurotwitter #NeuroTwitterNetwork #Neuroscience13/Preprint: bit.ly/3MVqXU9FANTASTIC team: @meyting3, Min Xie, @simonhhessBig thanks to mentors: @steveaschmd, T Bärnighausen, S VollmerAnd funders: @czbiohub @NIAIDNews@Stanford @StanfordDeptMed @StanfordMed @stanford_pcph @StanfordEpiNews @StanfordHP @StanPopHealthWould LOVE comments from the causal inference crowd #epitwitter #econtwitter @melodem_group @MariaGlymour @goodmanmetrics @BaiocchiMike @drehkopf @ProfMattFox @guido_imbens @Susan_Athey @ER_Mayeda @PennCausal @NoahHaber @AnupamBJena @JacobBor @societyforepi @JeremySussman …… dementia leaders @RudyTanzi @alzfdn @TheADDF @AlzResearchUK @CureAlzheimers @ABFbrain @FisherCenter @StanfordBrain @BrainResilience @Stanford_Neuro @NIHAging @NeuroscienceNew @DementiaAllianc @AlzDisInt @womensbrainpro @UsAgainstAlz @womensalz @_BrightFocus… sci comm leaders @hmkyale @EricTopol @Bob_Wachter @hubermanlab @davidasinclair @PeterAttiaMD @thehowie @foundmyfitness @docartemis @NakedScientists @profvrr @garwboy @sleepdiplomat @kevinmd @Rbaltman @choo_ek @NAChristakis @devisridhar @CarlosdelRio7… & colleagues @IDDocJen @nikkilsud @vcharuMD @dkowens @boussard @SalomonJA @NathanLo3579 @RanakTrivedi @JuliaRaifman @oziadias @BruceNeal1 @mbondy2 @HeartBobH @JasonAndrewsMD @Shuchi_Anand @SaraJeanSinger @jjaimemiranda @uniklinik_hd @StanfordCDH @LongevityCenter @StanfordDBDS• • •Missing some Tweet in this thread? summary:
- The shingles vaccine has been found to have a protective effect against dementia, particularly Alzheimer's disease.
- The study analyzed electronic health records and found that getting vaccinated reduces the chances of a dementia diagnosis by a fifth over a seven-year follow-up period.
- The study also found that the vaccine has no effect on other common causes of morbidity or mortality, and that it has a stronger protective effect on women compared to men. Further research is needed to determine the exact effect size and optimal population groups and time interval for vaccination, as well as to understand how the vaccine prevents or delays dementia.

hn_content: A study suggests that the shingles vaccine decreases the risk of getting dementia. Herpes viruses, including HSV1/2, may cause Alzheimer's, with the APOE4 genome making it worse. Other herpesvirus types can also be asymptomatic. There are ongoing efforts to develop cures and vaccines for herpes viruses, including chickenpox and shingles. Research shows that the chickenpox vaccine does not eliminate the risk of Alzheimer's, but it reduces the chances of contracting the varicella-zoster virus, which causes shingles. Epstein-Barr virus may be a key factor in multiple sclerosis, but there are no effective antivirals to treat it. People diagnosed with chronic herpes infections might be at risk of chickenpox-related dementia. Few first-line therapies are available, causing chronic mono patients to suffer fatigue and malaise with no cure in sight.Graduate school and academia can be difficult to navigate for people with disabilities, especially those with chronic illnesses and limited financial resources. Despite this, some individuals with disabilities continue to pursue STEM fields, such as software engineering and medical research, in hopes of making a difference. However, high barriers to entry and limited funding for research in certain fields can make it difficult for non-traditional candidates to participate. Additionally, evidence suggests that some chronic illnesses, such as multiple sclerosis and chronic fatigue syndrome, may be linked to certain viruses, such as Epstein-Barr virus and herpes simplex virus, creating further complications for individuals with these conditions. Despite these challenges, some companies and researchers are exploring new approaches, such as mRNA vaccines, to address disease.The article discusses how mutations in viruses can affect the effectiveness of vaccines. The spike protein in Covid-19, for example, was highly conserved until it mutated to evade the highly-specific immunity created by mRNA vaccines, resulting in the Omicron variant. mRNA vaccines, however, can "target specific sequences" and avoid problematic sequences. The article also includes discussions on nucleic-acid based vaccines and protein-based vaccines, as well as the positive impact of mRNA technology on rapid vaccine development. The comment section contains discussions on the cost and funding priorities of medical research, herpes zoster, and possible links between viral infections and dementia.A study on the potential link between the shingles vaccine and the prevention of Alzheimer's disease has found that being eligible for the vaccine can have a prophylactic effect against dementia. Researchers found a significant decrease in dementia rates in the vaccinated population born one week after the eligibility cut-off date compared to those born one week before the cut-off date. The study also found the protective effects were stronger for women than men, and that the vaccine may be beneficial against Alzheimer's but not vascular dementia. The apparent link raises questions about Alzheimer's as a potential virus-related disease. However, several commenters warned that the effect could be too small to prompt preventive measures and that the study only demonstrated an indirect link.A new study suggests the shingles vaccine might have "significant protective effects" against Alzheimer's disease in women. The study found that women who had received the shingles vaccine were found 70% less likely to develop Alzheimer's. Researchers suggest that the vaccine might stimulate immune cells to help clear the brain of toxic beta-amyloid and tau proteins, which have been linked to Alzheimer's. However, the results in men were inconclusive, with some suggesting that there was a potential protective effect that the study could not detect due to lack of statistical power. The Shingrix vaccine should still be taken to protect against shingles, as shingles is also a potentially debilitating illness.
hn_summary:
- The shingles vaccine may decrease the risk of developing dementia.
- Herpes viruses, including HSV1/2, may cause Alzheimer's, with the APOE4 genome making it worse.
- Ongoing research is exploring new approaches, such as mRNA vaccines, to address disease and viruses.

title: Amazon Backs Out of Climate Pledge, Deletes Shipment Zero Initiative Blogpost
content: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy. Jerod Harris/Getty Images for Vox MediaAmazon scrapped its Shipment Zero initiative, which was announced a few years ago.The company has rolled the goal into its broader Climate Pledge to become carbon-neutral by 2040.Amazon deleted the original Shipment Zero blog post. We dug it up.Often, it can feel like big corporations choose their bottom line when it comes to hard choices over profit versus the environment. Amazon is giving off that vibe this week.The ecommerce giant recently backed out of a commitment to make 50% of its shipments net-zero carbon by 2030. Amazon said in a statement that it would roll this goal into a broader Climate Pledge to reach net-zero carbon across all its operations by 2040. That's a decade later than the 50% goal, which was called "Shipment Zero" at the time."As we examined our work toward The Climate Pledge, we realized that it no longer made sense to have a separate and more narrow Shipment Zero goal that applied to only one part of our business, so we've decided to eliminate it," Amazon wrote in the statement.The investigative reporter Will Evans squeezed this information from Amazon and tweeted about it Thursday. Last year, Evans uncovered a study that said the company had drastically undercounted its carbon footprint. At the time, an Amazon spokesman reiterated the company's commitment to cutting emissions, including ordering a fleet of electric delivery vans and buying renewable energy for its electricity needs.Dropping the specific shipment pledge is noteworthy because Amazon's ecommerce operation relies on vast fleets of vehicles and aircraft to deliver packages to consumers quickly. Most of this activity chews up vast quantities of fossil fuels and spews out greenhouse gases. However, fast delivery is a key selling point for shoppers and the main reason millions subscribe to the company's Prime program.Amazon announced the Shipment Zero initiative in a blog a few years ago. The company has since deleted the post. However, through the magic of the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine, large corporations cannot rewrite online history. Here's a version of the blog.Some choice phrases from the announcement, so you can see what Amazon is backing out of now:"We can now see a path to net zero carbon delivery of shipments to customers, and we are setting an ambitious goal for ourselves to reach 50% of all Amazon shipments with net zero carbon by 2030.""We believe that lower costs include lowering the costs to the environment we all live and work in every day. We'll keep you posted as we work towards achieving Shipment Zero.""It won't be easy to achieve this goal, but it's worth being focused and stubborn on this vision and we're committed to seeing it through."Read nextE-CommerceAmazonAmazon Climate PledgeMore...
summary:
- Amazon has backed out of its Shipment Zero initiative, which aimed for 50% of its shipments to be net-zero carbon by 2030.
- The company will instead roll this goal into its broader Climate Pledge to become carbon-neutral by 2040.
- Amazon has deleted the original Shipment Zero blog post, but an archived version is available.

hn_content:
Amazon has backed out of its Climate Pledge and removed the Shipment Zero initiative. Amazon bought the naming rights for the Climate Pledge Arena in Seattle, yet public transportation infrastructure around the arena is considered horrendous, leading people to avoid it entirely. The West Seattle/Ballard Link Extensions may include stops at Seattle Center, but shovels will not be in the ground until 2026, and there is no ETA for completion. The slow progress in Seattle's planning and construction has been attributed to modern civil engineering methods being incredibly inefficient, as each possible way of building the infrastructure must be considered along each segment, including studying environmental impact, leading to massive delays. The tech industry in Seattle has grown faster than infrastructure can keep up with, leading to horrendous traffic and two-hour commutes.There is no meaningful content in this text.The article discusses the topic of holding corporations accountable for their carbon emissions goals. Some argue that companies that promote goals for PR purposes should be held accountable for missing them, while others believe that the focus should be on laws that set emissions limits. The idea of carbon offsetting is criticized as greenwashing accounting shenanigans. Microsoft is mentioned as the only hyperscaler that seems to take carbon emissions seriously, aiming for carbon zero by 2030. However, some criticize the emissions caused by resource-demanding OSes and unwanted features within them. One person quit Amazon Prime due to the environmental impact caused by delivery vans. Some argue that having fewer people driving to a neighborhood through delivery could be more efficient than people driving to stores individually.- Amazon is no longer committed to its pledge to reduce delivery emissions by 50% by 2030.
- Instead, the company is rolling the goal into a broader Climate Pledge.
- Some customers are unhappy and have canceled their Prime subscriptions in response to the news.
- There is debate over whether individual actions, such as canceling subscriptions, are effective in promoting change.
- Companies are struggling to balance environmental commitments and financial profits.
- The effectiveness of carbon offsets and biofuels as solutions to reducing emissions is disputed.
hn_summary:
- Amazon has backed out of its Climate Pledge and removed the Shipment Zero initiative.
- Some customers have canceled Prime subscriptions due to the change.
- Debate exists over the effectiveness of individual actions in promoting change, and the usefulness of carbon offsetting and biofuels in reducing emissions.

title: htmx
content: </> htmxdocsreferenceexamplestalkessays</> htmx high power tools for HTMLNEWS: We are excited to announce that htmx has been accepted into the first class of the Github Open Source Accelerator!introductionhtmx gives you access to AJAX, CSS Transitions, WebSockets and Server Sent Events directly in HTML, using attributes, so you can build modern user interfaces with the simplicity and power of hypertexthtmx is small (~14k min.gz’d), dependency-free, extendable, IE11 compatible & has reduced code base sizes by 67% when compared with reactmotivationWhy should only <a> and <form> be able to make HTTP requests?Why should only click & submit events trigger them?Why should only GET & POST methods be available?Why should you only be able to replace the entire screen?By removing these arbitrary constraints, htmx completes HTML as a hypertextquick start <script src="https://unpkg.com/htmx.org@1.9.2"></script> <!-- have a button POST a click via AJAX --> <button hx-post="/clicked" hx-swap="outerHTML">  Click Me </button>The hx-post and hx-swap attributes on this button tell htmx:“When a user clicks on this button, issue an AJAX request to /clicked, and replace the entire button with the HTML response”htmx is the successor to intercooler.jsRead the docs introduction for a more in-depth… introduction.sponsorshtmx development can be supported via Github SponsorsThank you to all our generous supporters, including:ʕ •ᴥ•ʔ made in montanahaikujavascript fatigue:longing for a hypertextalready in handdocsreferenceexamplestalkessays@htmx_org

HTMX is based on HyperTalk, the scripting language of HyperCard, while incorporating web-specific syntax. HTMX allows developers to write web apps the way they did in 1999, but with the ability to update pages partially, make forms more dynamic, and create interactive features with ease. Many developers have used HTMX to build small or medium-scale projects, such as internal tools or marketing agency websites that require simple forms and dynamic features. By submitting a form with a post request and then loading an entire page with a thank you message, the local hair salon taking reservations, mom and pop store's contact form, or a local newspaper's letter to the editor form can be done without htmx or JavaScript. title: Layoffs push down scores on Glassdoor – how companies respond
content:
Several tech companies are flagging negative reviews on Glassdoor for removal and encouraging staff to post 5-star reviews to balance out the negative. Glassdoor is able to remove unfavorable reviews that violate its guidelines; however, they do not notify the user whose review was removed and do not share the reasons behind removing the review. Glassdoor is a neutral platform that enforces its own terms and conditions but could make the process clearer by publishing a moderation log explaining why a review was removed. Companies often encourage employees to leave positive reviews on Glassdoor, ranging from sending out reminders to organizing review events. Some companies even asked employees to leave a positive review during their first week of work. Some companies saw an increase in their Glassdoor scores after layoffs, like Trustwave, with anonymous “spam” reviews contributing heavily to the score increase.- Fake 5-star Glassdoor reviews have a going rate of $10-25 per review on marketplaces, according to solution scientist Shikhar Sachdev's investigation of the underground economy of Glassdoor reviews.
- It is advised to approach Glassdoor reviews with caution and context, considering the potential for fake reviews.
- The full 'The Scoop' edition covers exclusive topics like the weight to assign to Glassdoor reviews, when Amazon will join the generative AI race, a 1.5 month-long code freeze at Stack Overflow, early warning of recent layoffs at AWS and NVIDIA's earnings revealing bigger-than-expected demand for hardware to run and train AI models.
- 'The Scoop' provides inside information on Big Tech and high-growth startups, and is highly relevant for software engineers and managers in the tech industry.
summary:
- Tech companies are asking staff to post positive reviews on Glassdoor to balance out negative ones, and they can also flag negative reviews for removal.
- Glassdoor does not notify users when their reviews are removed or provide reasons why; a moderation log could make the process clearer.
- Be cautious when viewing Glassdoor reviews, as fake 5-star reviews can be purchased for $10-25 each. Check for context and consider the potential for fake reviews.

title: Tesla Model Y overtakes Corolla to be world's best-selling car in 2023
content: 19 COMMENTSTesla Model Y overtakes Corolla to be world’s best-selling car in 2023MAY 26, 202319 COMMENTS2 MINUTE READRIZ AKHTARTESLA IMPACT REPORTSHARETWEETThe Tesla Model Y electric crossover is now the best-selling car in the world, knocking the Toyota Corolla from the top of the podium. New data from JATO Dynamics has revealed that in the first quarter of 2023 the Tesla Model Y is the best-selling car in the world, selling 267,200 in the first three months of the year, eclipsing Toyota Corolla’s 256,400 sales.This was predicted a few years ago by Tesla boss Elon Musk before the car was even launched and now it’s happened.Here in Australia, Tesla Model Y has been a hugely popular model since its launch in June last year and is already the second best selling SUV of any type, just behind the Toyota RAV4.It has sold more than 14,000 of these electric SUVs in Australia. This year, over 5,000 have been sold with this quarter looking to be its best so far. The start of it saw April’s sales coming up to 2,095 according to data from FCAI vFacts.SOURCE: VFACTSThe sales continue to rise in Australia, despite the vehicle price not qualifying for many state and territory incentives due to its higher starting price when compared to the Tesla Model 3.When comparing it to ICE vehicles, the Tesla Model Y is the best-selling Medium SUV in the over $60,000, in the country by a wide margin. With 5,264 sales, it far outpaces the next best-selling Medium SUV which is the Audi !5 with 1,618 sales.Earlier this year, data compiled by Tesla and EV News enthusiast Sawyer Merritt on Twitter shows how Model Y has fared in total sales when compared to the world’s best-selling vehicles in 2022.This is a huge milestone for the EV transition. It shows legacy automakers that the time to produce and sell more compelling EVs is now if they are to survive the automotive valley of death.Riz AkhtarRiz is the founder of carloop based in Melbourne, specialising in Australian EV data, insight reports and trends. He is a mechanical engineer who spent the first 7 years of his career building transport infrastructure before starting carloop. He has a passion for cars, particularly EVs and wants to help reduce transport emissions in Australia. He currently drives a red Tesla Model 3.SHARETWEETRelated TopicsELECTRIC CAR SALESMODEL YTESLA
summary:
- The Tesla Model Y electric crossover has become the best-selling car in the world, selling 267,200 units in the first quarter of 2023.
- This milestone has been achieved ahead of Tesla boss Elon Musk's predictions before the car was even launched.
- The Model Y has been hugely popular in Australia, selling over 14,000 units, and continuing to rise in sales despite higher starting prices than other EVs.

title: Mozilla stops Firefox fullscreen VPN ads after user outrage
content: Mozilla stops Firefox fullscreen VPN ads after user outrageBy Bill ToulasMay 26, 2023 10:52 AM 7Firefox users have been complaining about very intrusive full-screen advertisements promoting Mozilla VPN displayed in the web browser when navigating an unrelated page.The ads popping in Firefox disable the web browser's functionality, denying users access to the interface and graying out everything in the background until they close them.Some users reported on Reddit that the annoying full-screen ads even cause Firefox to become unresponsive for up to 30 seconds, forcing them to terminate the browser's process.Top StoriesREAD MOREThe Week in Ransomware - May 26th 2023 -Cities Under AttackBesides the disruptive nature of the advertisement, Firefox users showed their irritation at the aggressive promoting method from a company that theoretically has great respect for user choice and claims to value a people-first experience.The advertisement boosts Mozilla VPN, a paid open-source VPN service that constitutes a crucial revenue source for the not-for-profit company.Advert randomly served to Firefox users (Bugzilla)Mozilla VPN is not available worldwide, only in the United States, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Malaysia, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Singapore, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and the UK; so it is safe to assume that only users from these regions saw the overlay ads in Firefox.Mozilla switches off the adsThe Firefox user community immediately expressed indignation towards Mozilla’s blatant product promotional practice by filing multiple reports on Bugzilla.The most recent relevant report on Mozilla’s bug tracking platform received the "RESOLVED WORKSFORME" tag, which means that ads work as intended and there is nothing to fix.BleepingComputer has contacted Mozilla about the matter and received the following statement following the barrage of complaints from Firefox users:"We’re continuously working to understand the best ways to communicate with people who use Firefox. Ultimately, we accomplished the exact opposite of what we intended in this experiment and quickly rolled the experience back. We apologize for any confusion or concern" - MozillaA quick solution for people who find Mozilla VPN ads unacceptable is to open Firefox, enter “about:config” in the URL bar, and then set browser.vpn_promo.enabled to false by clicking to toggle button on the right.Disabling the VPN ad from Firefox advanced settings (BleepingComputer)Alternatively, users may install an ad blocker like AdGuard, which some people reported that it was effective in blocking the pop-up.Related Articles:Firefox now blocks cross-site tracking by default for all usersZyxel warns of critical vulnerabilities in firewall and VPN devicesGet multi-layer protection with this $199.99 DPN hardware dealMicrosoft investigates slow Windows VPN speeds after May updatesBrave unveils new "Forgetful Browsing" anti-tracking feature
summary:
- Firefox users have been complaining about intrusive full-screen ads promoting Mozilla VPN that disable web browser functionality and cause unresponsiveness.
- Mozilla faced criticism for the aggressive advertising method that contradicted their respect for user choice and people-first experience values.
- After the user outrage, Mozilla issued an apology and turned off the fullscreen VPN ads, and users can also disable the VPN ad by following a quick solution or using ad blockers like AdGuard.

hn_content: Mozilla has stopped displaying full-screen VPN ads on Firefox after users expressed outrage. A recent ad-caused popping up on an unrelated web page and considered being detrimental to the experience. A notable long-time Firefox user reported changing sentiments the first time in over 20 years using the browser. The article mentions previous similar controversial moves by Mozilla in 2017 and claims the current display shows an arrogance not typical of a browser provider supposedly focusing on user privacy. Some reports claim that Mozilla may find these non-traditional ways of promoting its VPN service detrimental to its reputation. Discussions on the use of conspiracy theories, future Firefox updates, Brave browser as well as Firefox's competitors Safari and Edge are also mentioned.Firefox users express frustration with the browser in a discussion on Hacker News. Users comment on their dislike for Firefox and their experiences switching to alternative browsers such as Brave, Duck, and Vivaldi. Some also criticize Firefox's recent experiment with an ad overlay, which they perceive as a fundamental misunderstanding of what Firefox was built on. Many users are disappointed with Mozilla's recent direction and management, leading to commentary on the decline of Firefox. Despite these issues, some users still prefer Firefox to its competitors due to its extensibility and customization options.Mozilla's recent experiment of promoting its paid VPN service through a user-hostile advertisement has caused backlash, with users criticizing the design and questioning whether Mozilla can still be considered a non-profit. The advertisement was part of Firefox's interface, and some users reported difficulty closing it. The incident has led to concerns about accountability and decision-making at Mozilla. Some users have started looking for alternative browsers, with suggestions ranging from Safari to Falkon to ungoogled-chromium. Some advocate for Firefox to adopt a freemium model, while others argue for a decentralization of open-source browser development. There are also questions raised about the accuracy of labeling Mozilla as non-profit. The incident emphasizes the importance of considering user experience and incentives in tech business models.Firefox faced criticism for displaying an unskippable promotional message for Mozilla's VPN service. Although Firefox claimed it was an accidental experiment, users expressed their disapproval, and Mozilla reverted the feature. The incident raises questions about user privacy and the use of obtrusive advertisements by browser developers. Some users considered switching to alternative browsers such as Vivaldi or Brave, which were seen as better alternatives to Firefox and Chrome. Others suggested creating new browsers or forking the Firefox project to return to a mostly volunteer model focused on the browser. Some people preferred the Mullvad VPN service, which powered Mozilla's VPN and did not pay for commission or special sale prices, avoiding conflicts of interest.Mozilla, the developers of the Firefox browser, faced criticism from users after injecting a sponsored ad campaign into the browser chrome, causing a pop-up ad to appear. This is not the first time Mozilla has injected ads into the browser chrome, previously doing so in 2018 with a plugin that was force-installed on users. The move has sparked concerns about user privacy and potential distrust towards Mozilla. The post also includes a sarcastic comment about the situation. No new or exciting developments or releases are mentioned in the post.
hn_summary:
- Mozilla has stopped displaying full-screen VPN ads on Firefox due to user outrage and negative impact on user experience.
- Users criticize Mozilla for recent experimental promotions of its VPN service and question its non-profit status.
- Some users switch to alternative browsers such as Brave or Vivaldi due to disappointment with Mozilla's recent direction and management.

title: There oughta be a bullet time video booth
content: An expert journalist recounts his experience creating a video booth with a bullet time effect for his cousin's wedding. He used an array of twelve old DSLRs arranged in an arch, triggering them simultaneously to create the effect. He combined sequences from multiple guests to create longer bullet time footage and used DaVinci Resolve to smoothly slow down the effect. He also included a main 1080p camera and mounted everything on a quarter circle stand made from a B-stock e-drum rack. The biggest challenge was powering the cameras, and the author had to experiment with multiple USB chargers before finding a reliable solution. Despite the setbacks, the resulting video was a unique and memorable way to capture memories at the wedding.A DIY bullet time video booth was created using multiple cameras, a Raspberry Pi Pico, Bluetooth push buttons, and video lights. Cameras were controlled via USB and triggered using a simple circuit with the Canon trigger input. Push buttons were made wireless using a Bluetooth module on the Pi Pico and powered by AA batteries. Video lights were brought to ensure consistency in exposure throughout the day. The preview and idle loop were displayed on an old Dell XPS 12, while the post-processing was done manually in DaVinci Resolve. The project was implemented using Python code and gphoto2, while the interface was built using Flask and shown in Chromium.A tech-savvy individual created a DIY photo booth with a bullet time effect using 13 cameras that recorded stabilized versions of all recordings with different amounts of artificial frames and generated transitions with airborne kids, flowing hair, and flying items with DaVinci Resolve through Python automation. The project required an appropriate understanding of technology and spare time and was not suitable for a bride or groom to set up on their wedding day, given the potential technical difficulties. The bullet time effect was a fantastic alternative to the traditional photo booth, and guests enjoyed posing in front of the camera array and playing with the effect, particularly later in the evening. The video booth relies on DIY infrared remote and wifi SD card interfaces to start recording and retrieving the results.
summary:
- An expert journalist created a memorable DIY video booth with a bullet time effect using an array of cameras for a wedding.
- A newer version of the DIY video booth used a Raspberry Pi Pico, wireless Bluetooth push buttons, and video lights, controlled using Python code and gphoto2.
- The bullet time effect created fantastic footage but can be technically challenging and not suitable for a wedding event without proper preparation.

hn_content: A thread on Hacker News discusses the affordability and quality of DSLR cameras for photography enthusiasts, as well as the growing popularity of mirrorless cameras. The thread also includes tips for using older cameras as webcams and for creating "bullet time" effects with rotating platforms or camera arrays. While some express interest in the technique, others voice concerns about the need for choreography and proper timing to create effective sequences. Additionally, readers speculate about potential applications for such equipment.A Reddit post shares an innovative idea for a DIY bullet-time photo booth, using DSLR cameras, a rig made of PVC pipes, and custom-written code to synchronize the cameras. The resulting footage is a choppy but novel 2-second, 60-frame scene of a pitch being thrown, a technique first popularized in the 1999 movie "The Matrix". The post also includes discussions on the technical challenges of using synchronized camera arrays for bullet-time effects, alternative methods such as AI in-betweening and Neural Radiance Fields, and existing commercial offerings for bullet-time booths. Despite some limitations and complexities, the DIY solution offers a fun and unique experience that could be adapted to different events and settings.
